data.title: Timeline of Events
data.meta_description: Timelines help you organize the historical events you’ve learned about so you can see how they relate to one another. They are usually organized chronologically, which means in date order. The timeline below is separated into two parts: New Hampshire events and events happening elsewhere in America and sometimes the world. An event on one side of the timeline might influence an event on the other side in the same way that New Hampshire is influenced by events in America and the world. You can also see how the Granite State has made a big impact on America.
data.text:
Ice Age in New Hampshire

CLOSE

Ice Age in New Hampshire

Millions of years ago, most of North America, and all of New Hampshire, was covered in ice. These large sheets of ice and snow covered the land for a very long time. This period was known as the Ice Age. There was very little plant or animal life that survived it.

Learn More

Ice Age in New Hampshire

Circa 2.6 million years BCE

Caption:

Millions of years ago, most of North America, and all of New Hampshire, was covered in ice. These large sheets of ice and snow covered the land for a very long time. This period was known as the Ice Age. There was very little plant or animal life that survived it.

Glaciers melt in New Hampshire

CLOSE

Glaciers melt in New Hampshire

As the ice melted, it left its mark upon the land. Deep holes became lakes. Valleys where the ice had been became rivers. As the ice receded and the temperature warmed up, plant and animal life began to flourish.

Learn More

Glaciers melt in New Hampshire

Circa 14,000–9,000 BCE

Caption:

As the ice melted, it left its mark upon the land. Deep holes became lakes. Valleys where the ice had been became rivers. As the ice receded and the temperature warmed up, plant and animal life began to flourish.

Abenaki settle in New Hampshire

CLOSE

Abenaki settle in New Hampshire

The earliest known settlers in New Hampshire were Native Americans known as the Abenaki. The Abenaki, like most Native Americans in North America, originally came from Asia. Thousands of years ago, they crossed a land bridge linking what is now Russia to the Asian continent...

Learn More

Abenaki settle in New Hampshire

Circa 10,000-8,000 BCE

Caption:

The earliest known settlers in New Hampshire were Native Americans known as the Abenaki. The Abenaki, like most Native Americans in North America, originally came from Asia. Thousands of years ago, they crossed a land bridge linking what is now Russia to the Asian continent. Gradually, the Abenaki moved east across the North American continent until settling in what is now northern New England and parts of Canada.

Abenaki develop agriculture

CLOSE

Abenaki develop agriculture

The Abenaki were originally hunters and gatherers. They got their food by hunting and fishing and by gathering nuts and berries that grew in the forests. Then around 3,000 years ago, they began to grow crops to provide more food. Native tribes grew three kinds of crops—squash, corn, and beans...

Learn More

Abenaki develop agriculture

Circa 1,000 BCE

Caption:

The Abenaki were originally hunters and gatherers. They got their food by hunting and fishing and by gathering nuts and berries that grew in the forests. Then around 3,000 years ago, they began to grow crops to provide more food. Native tribes grew three kinds of crops—squash, corn, and beans. This trio became known as the “three sisters” because they were all grown together. The corn grew straight and tall, and the beans grew up around the corn stalks. The squash was planted at the base of the corn stalks, and its big leaves protected the base of the corn and beans, preventing weeds from growing or animals from eating them.

Christopher Columbus reaches North America

CLOSE

Christopher Columbus reaches North America

Christopher Columbus was an Italian explorer. He “discovered” America--even though there were Native American people already living here. After Columbus’s voyage to what became called the “New World,” many Europeans were interested in both North America and South America...

Learn More

Christopher Columbus reaches North America

1492

Caption:

Christopher Columbus was an Italian explorer. He “discovered” America--even though there were Native American people already living here. After Columbus’s voyage to what became called the “New World,” many Europeans were interested in both North America and South America. Europeans began coming to the Americas to look for treasures like gold and silver. Some of them built settlements and claimed land for European countries like Spain, England, and France.

Jamestown established

CLOSE

Jamestown established

The first English settlement in America was in Virginia in 1607. The colonists named their settlement Jamestown after the English king, James I. Life was very hard for these settlers because they had come looking for gold and did not bring enough food to eat...

Learn More

Jamestown established

1607

Caption:

The first English settlement in America was in Virginia in 1607. The colonists named their settlement Jamestown after the English king, James I. Life was very hard for these settlers because they had come looking for gold and did not bring enough food to eat. For the first several years, the Native Americans shared their food with the English colonists so they would not starve. Eventually, the colonists learned to plant crops and live off the land. Many more English settlers arrived in Jamestown and founded new settlements in Virginia. They were hoping to build a better life than they had in England.

John Smith lands at Isles of Shoals

CLOSE

John Smith lands at Isles of Shoals

In the early 1600s, a few European explorers came to New England. Among them was Captain John Smith, who was famous for helping to found the Jamestown colony in Virginia. Smith landed on a small group of islands off the coast of New Hampshire in 1614...

Learn More

John Smith lands at Isles of Shoals

1614

Caption:

In the early 1600s, a few European explorers came to New England. Among them was Captain John Smith, who was famous for helping to found the Jamestown colony in Virginia. Smith landed on a small group of islands off the coast of New Hampshire in 1614. He originally named the largest island after himself—Smith Island—but today we know all of these islands as the Isles of Shoals. When Smith returned to England he wrote a book about what he had seen in New England and told his readers that there were more fish in New England waters than anyone could imagine. He also wrote about how beautiful the land was, how plentiful the trees and animals were, and how perfect it would be to settle there. His book encouraged many people to think about coming to New England.

Disease strikes the Abenaki

CLOSE

Disease strikes the Abenaki

The Europeans who visited New England accidently brought with them diseases like small pox and chicken pox. Unfortunately, thousands of the Abenaki caught these diseases and became sick. Since the Abenaki were not used to European diseases, their bodies had no resistance to the infections...

Learn More

Disease strikes the Abenaki

1616–1619

Caption:

The Europeans who visited New England accidently brought with them diseases like small pox and chicken pox. Unfortunately, thousands of the Abenaki caught these diseases and became sick. Since the Abenaki were not used to European diseases, their bodies had no resistance to the infections. More than three-quarters of the Abenaki became sick and died from these diseases, and sometimes diseases wiped out entire villages of Native Americans.

Pilgrims land at Plymouth

CLOSE

Pilgrims land at Plymouth

A second group of English colonists, called the Pilgrims, landed in Massachusetts in 1620. The Pilgrims came to America because they wanted to practice their religion freely. They built a settlement that they named Plymouth Plantation...

Learn More

Pilgrims land at Plymouth

1620

Caption:

A second group of English colonists, called the Pilgrims, landed in Massachusetts in 1620. The Pilgrims came to America because they wanted to practice their religion freely. They built a settlement that they named Plymouth Plantation. They also wrote the Mayflower Compact, which was a set of laws for them to live by. Life was very hard for the Pilgrims because they did not have enough food, but the Native Americans helped them learn how to survive in the New World. In the coming years, thousands of people came to Massachusetts because they wanted to live where they would be free to practice their own religion.

First English settlement in New Hampshire

CLOSE

First English settlement in New Hampshire

The first permanent European settlement in New Hampshire was at Odiorne Point in Rye. A group of English settlers led by a man named David Thomson came to the area mainly to fish. They built stone houses because they planned to stay year-round, even through the winter...

Learn More

First English settlement in New Hampshire

1623

Caption:

The first permanent European settlement in New Hampshire was at Odiorne Point in Rye. A group of English settlers led by a man named David Thomson came to the area mainly to fish. They built stone houses because they planned to stay year-round, even through the winter. Other Englishmen soon joined them and made their own settlements along the coast of New Hampshire and eventually inland.

John Mason founds New Hampshire

CLOSE

John Mason founds New Hampshire

Although other Englishmen came to New Hampshire in the early 1600s, the founder of New Hampshire was a man named Captain John Mason. He named this land after his home county in England, Hampshire. Mason planned to bring his wife and newborn baby with him when he and a group of settlers came to the New World in 1635...

Learn More

John Mason founds New Hampshire

1629

Caption:

Although other Englishmen came to New Hampshire in the early 1600s, the founder of New Hampshire was a man named Captain John Mason. He named this land after his home county in England, Hampshire. Mason planned to bring his wife and newborn baby with him when he and a group of settlers came to the New World in 1635. They planned to make money from all the fish in the waters off New Hampshire’s coast. They also thought they could trade with the Native Americans for beaver pelts, which were very popular in England. Unfortunately, Mason died unexpectedly before leaving England. For nearly 100 years afterward, his heirs fought to protect their claim to New Hampshire.

Darby Field ascends Mount Washington

CLOSE

Darby Field ascends Mount Washington

At more than 6,000 feet, Mount Washington is the tallest mountain in New England. The first person to climb it was an Englishman named Darby Field. The Abenaki had warned Field that it was dangerous to go to the top of Mount Washington because of “evil spirits,” but the real danger was the terrible weather conditions so high up...

Learn More

Darby Field ascends Mount Washington

1642

Caption:

At more than 6,000 feet, Mount Washington is the tallest mountain in New England. The first person to climb it was an Englishman named Darby Field. The Abenaki had warned Field that it was dangerous to go to the top of Mount Washington because of “evil spirits,” but the real danger was the terrible weather conditions so high up. No one knows why Field was so determined to make such a difficult climb, although there were rumors at the time that there were precious gems, like diamonds, high up in the mountains. After Field's climb to the top, no one else seemed interested in Mount Washington until after the American Revolution, more than 100 years later.

Passaconaway’s farewell

CLOSE

Passaconaway’s farewell

For most of the 1600s, the leader of the Abenaki in southern New Hampshire was a man named Passaconaway. He was the sachem, or chief, of the Pennacook tribe, which included as many as 12,000 people...

Learn More

Passaconaway’s farewell

1660

Caption:

For most of the 1600s, the leader of the Abenaki in southern New Hampshire was a man named Passaconaway. He was the sachem, or chief, of the Pennacook tribe, which included as many as 12,000 people. Passaconaway was greatly respected by his people, and many believed he had all sorts of mystical powers to summon huge storms and talk to animals like bears. Although no one knows when Passaconaway was born, he was rumored to be over 100 years old when he stepped down as leader to his people. Passaconaway believed the Abenaki should live with the English settlers in peace. In his last speech, he urged his people to work with the English.

Scots-Irish come to New Hampshire

CLOSE

Scots-Irish come to New Hampshire

In the 1600s, European settlers to New Hampshire were from England. In 1719, a new group of settlers came here. They were known as the Scots-Irish. A group of 16 families founded a settlement in Nutfield, which later became the town of Londonderry...

Learn More

Scots-Irish come to New Hampshire

1719

Caption:

In the 1600s, European settlers to New Hampshire were from England. In 1719, a new group of settlers came here. They were known as the Scots-Irish. A group of 16 families founded a settlement in Nutfield, which later became the town of Londonderry. Over the next several decades, thousands of Scots-Irish came to New England, and many of them passed through Nutfield as they decided where to live. New Hampshire has a strong tradition of Scots-Irish culture, and many people here are descended from the Scots-Irish. The Scots-Irish in Londonderry also planted the first potatoes in North America.

Benning Wentworth appointed first colonial governor

CLOSE

Benning Wentworth appointed first colonial governor

When New Hampshire was first founded, it shared a government with Massachusetts. They both had the same governor, and at one point, there was even talk about making all of New Hampshire a county in Massachusetts! Most people living in New Hampshire did not want to be part of Massachusetts, and they asked King George II of England to keep them separate and give them their own governor...

Learn More

Benning Wentworth appointed first colonial governor

1741

Caption:

When New Hampshire was first founded, it shared a government with Massachusetts. They both had the same governor, and at one point, there was even talk about making all of New Hampshire a county in Massachusetts! Most people living in New Hampshire did not want to be part of Massachusetts, and they asked King George II of England to keep them separate and give them their own governor. The king agreed and appointed Benning Wentworth the governor of New Hampshire. Wentworth was from an old New Hampshire family, and under his rule, New Hampshire became completely separate from Massachusetts.

Stamp Act protests

CLOSE

Stamp Act protests

By the 1760s, many people in New Hampshire—and America—were getting tired of being British colonies and having to pay taxes to the British government. In 1765, the British imposed a new tax called the Stamp Act, which put a tax on books, newspapers, documents, playing cards, and anything made of paper...

Learn More

Stamp Act protests

1765

Caption:

By the 1760s, many people in New Hampshire—and America—were getting tired of being British colonies and having to pay taxes to the British government. In 1765, the British imposed a new tax called the Stamp Act, which put a tax on books, newspapers, documents, playing cards, and anything made of paper. People all over America protested against the new tax, including in Portsmouth, which was the biggest city in New Hampshire at that time. This protest was an important first step in convincing the people of New Hampshire that they needed to be independent from Great Britain.

Pine Tree Riot

CLOSE

Pine Tree Riot

One of the British laws that the people of New Hampshire did not like involved pine trees! The British government declared that all the big pine trees in New Hampshire belonged to the king, who used them as ships’ masts for the British navy...

Learn More

Pine Tree Riot

1772

Caption:

One of the British laws that the people of New Hampshire did not like involved pine trees! The British government declared that all the big pine trees in New Hampshire belonged to the king, who used them as ships’ masts for the British navy. Many people in New Hampshire ignored the law, but then a group of people in Goffstown and Weare got caught cutting down some big pine trees for their own use. They had to pay a fine for breaking the law. Some of them paid the fine, but the people living in Weare refused to pay it. When the sheriff came to arrest them, they ran him out of town in the middle of the night. This became known as the Pine Tree Riot. It is an example of how the people of New Hampshire were frustrated by being under British rule.

Attack on Fort William and Mary

CLOSE

Attack on Fort William and Mary

In December 1774, an American patriot named Paul Revere rode to Portsmouth, New Hampshire, to warn his friends that the British army was going to send more soldiers and supplies to Fort William and Mary in Portsmouth Harbor...

Learn More

Attack on Fort William and Mary

1774

Caption:

In December 1774, an American patriot named Paul Revere rode to Portsmouth, New Hampshire, to warn his friends that the British army was going to send more soldiers and supplies to Fort William and Mary in Portsmouth Harbor. The Americans wanted to keep the British army out of New Hampshire, so they captured Fort William and Mary from the few British soldiers who were stationed there. This action was the first conflict between the Americans and the British in what would become known as the American Revolution.

American Revolution

CLOSE

American Revolution

By the 1760s, most of the colonies in North America belonged to England (which was also known as Britain or Great Britain). The British had not paid much attention to America over the years, and the Americans were used to making their own decisions and laws...

Learn More

American Revolution

1775–1783

Caption:

By the 1760s, most of the colonies in North America belonged to England (which was also known as Britain or Great Britain). The British had not paid much attention to America over the years, and the Americans were used to making their own decisions and laws. They did not want the British telling them what to do, and they did not want to pay taxes to the British government. In 1775, fighting broke out between the Americans and the British, starting a war that became known as the American Revolution. The war lasted until 1783, but by the end of it, the Americans had beaten the British and earned the right to start their own country.

Bunker Hill

CLOSE

Bunker Hill

The Battle of Bunker Hill was the first major battle of the American Revolution. The British army, which was very well trained, attacked American troops in the hills surrounding Boston. The American troops did not have much experience as soldiers, but they put up a good fight against the British...

Learn More

Bunker Hill

1775

Caption:

The Battle of Bunker Hill was the first major battle of the American Revolution. The British army, which was very well trained, attacked American troops in the hills surrounding Boston. The American troops did not have much experience as soldiers, but they put up a good fight against the British. Although the British won the battle, the Americans fought very well. It made the British realize that the Americans were going to be hard to beat in this war. Many of the Americans who fought in this battle were from New Hampshire!

New Hampshire declares independence

CLOSE

New Hampshire declares independence

On January 4, 1776, New Hampshire became the first British colony to declare its independence from Great Britain. Since New Hampshire was now an independent state, its leaders wrote a new constitution for it, which laid out how the government would function. New Hampshire, therefore, formed the first state government in America...

Learn More

New Hampshire declares independence

1776

Caption:

On January 4, 1776, New Hampshire became the first British colony to declare its independence from Great Britain. Since New Hampshire was now an independent state, its leaders wrote a new constitution for it, which laid out how the government would function. New Hampshire, therefore, formed the first state government in America.

Declaration of Independence

CLOSE

Declaration of Independence

During the American Revolution, the Americans created a congress to pass laws for the colonies and to raise taxes to support the war effort. On July 4, 1776, this congress approved a document called the Declaration of Independence...

Learn More

Declaration of Independence

1776

Caption:

During the American Revolution, the Americans created a congress to pass laws for the colonies and to raise taxes to support the war effort. On July 4, 1776, this congress approved a document called the Declaration of Independence. The Declaration of Independence explained to the world why the Americans could no longer live as British colonies and needed to be independent. The Declaration included some ideas that would become very important to the new American nation, such as that all men are created equal.

Battle of Bennington

CLOSE

Battle of Bennington

In the summer of 1777, the British army launched a massive campaign through the Hudson River Valley in New York and Vermont to divide the New England colonies from the rest of America. Fighting between the British and Americans went on all summer, but in the middle of August, New Hampshire’s General John Stark arrived in southern Vermont with a large group of New Hampshire soldiers...

Learn More

Battle of Bennington

1777

Caption:

In the summer of 1777, the British army launched a massive campaign through the Hudson River Valley in New York and Vermont to divide the New England colonies from the rest of America. Fighting between the British and Americans went on all summer, but in the middle of August, New Hampshire’s General John Stark arrived in southern Vermont with a large group of New Hampshire soldiers. They fought a portion of the British army near a town called Bennington and won. Stark’s victory kept the British from gathering supplies and cost the British army many men who were captured, wounded, or killed. The British defeat at Bennington weakened them. A few months later, the Americans won an even bigger victory against the British at the Battle of Saratoga, which was the turning point of the American Revolution.

Freedom Petition

CLOSE

Freedom Petition

New Hampshire used to have enslaved people. The first enslaved people in America were kidnapped in Africa and brought to the New World where they were sold for their labor. They had to work for their masters without being paid, and they weren't allowed to make their own decisions about their lives. Their children were also enslaved, and their grandchildren and so on. Most enslaved people in America lived in the South, but even colonies in the North, like New Hampshire and Massachusetts, had enslaved people.

Learn More

Freedom Petition

1779

Caption:

New Hampshire used to have enslaved people. The first enslaved people in America were kidnapped in Africa and brought to the New World where they were sold for their labor. They had to work for their masters without being paid, and they weren't allowed to make their own decisions about their lives. Their children were also enslaved, and their grandchildren and so on. Most enslaved people in America lived in the South, but even colonies in the North, like New Hampshire and Massachusetts, had enslaved people. During the American Revolution, when people were talking about the importance of freedom and equality, many enslaved people started to question why they weren’t also free. In Portsmouth, 20 enslaved people wrote a very well-crafted petition to the new state government. They argued that if America was a land of freedom, then they should not have to live as slaves. The state government did not act on the petition or free them from slavery.

New Hampshire ratifies the U.S. Constitution

CLOSE

New Hampshire ratifies the U.S. Constitution

When the 13 American colonies declared themselves independent from Britain, they had to form a government for their new country. They had to decide how political power was going to be shared between the states and the federal government and develop a process for passing laws that would govern the new country...

Learn More

New Hampshire ratifies the U.S. Constitution

1788

Caption:

When the 13 American colonies declared themselves independent from Britain, they had to form a government for their new country. They had to decide how political power was going to be shared between the states and the federal government and develop a process for passing laws that would govern the new country. At first they wrote a document called the Articles of Confederation, but the Articles didn’t work very well and they set them aside. Next they wrote a document called the Constitution. For the Constitution to go into effect, 9 of the 13 states had to agree to it, which is called ratifying. In June 1788, New Hampshire ratified the new Constitution and was the 9th state to do so. Even though other states ratified the Constitution too, New Hampshire’s vote meant the new Constitution could go into effect.

U.S. Constitution

CLOSE

U.S. Constitution

After the Americans won the American Revolution, they had to create a new form of government for their new country. It took them several years to figure out which form of government would work best for them. They knew the government would be a democracy, meaning the people would get to vote about how they would be governed...

Learn More

U.S. Constitution

1789

Caption:

After the Americans won the American Revolution, they had to create a new form of government for their new country. It took them several years to figure out which form of government would work best for them. They knew the government would be a democracy, meaning the people would get to vote about how they would be governed. But they didn’t want any one part of the government to get too strong because then the government might not listen to what the people wanted. In 1789, the founding fathers adopted a document called the Constitution. It explained how the national government would be organized into three branches with the president of the United States in one branch, the U.S. Congress in another branch, and the U.S. Supreme Court in a third. These three branches work together to pass laws and govern the country, just as the Constitution explained. George Washington became the first U.S. president.

Ona Judge flees slavery

CLOSE

Ona Judge flees slavery

In 1796, an enslaved woman named Ona Judge ran away from her master in the South and came to New Hampshire. Her master was George Washington, the president of the United States. Washington owned many slaves at his plantation in Virginia, and he wasn’t willing to just let Ona go...

Learn More

Ona Judge flees slavery

1796

Caption:

In 1796, an enslaved woman named Ona Judge ran away from her master in the South and came to New Hampshire. Her master was George Washington, the president of the United States. Washington owned many slaves at his plantation in Virginia, and he wasn’t willing to just let Ona go. Instead, he tried to catch her and bring her back to slavery. Slavery was not very popular in New Hampshire by this point, though, and New Hampshire authorities refused to help Washington capture her, even if he was the president. Although Ona always worried about being recaptured, she never was, and lived the rest of her life in New Hampshire.

Roads across the state

CLOSE

Roads across the state

There were no big roads in New Hampshire during the 1700s like the highways we have today. Instead, all the roads in the state were local, linking one village to another. Each town was responsible for building and repairing their own roads, and sometimes the towns didn’t do a great job of it. In the late 1700s, some investors got together and decided to build a nice, big road that would run across the middle of the state, from Portsmouth to Concord...

Learn More

Roads across the state

1796

Caption:

There were no big roads in New Hampshire during the 1700s like the highways we have today. Instead, all the roads in the state were local, linking one village to another. Each town was responsible for building and repairing their own roads, and sometimes the towns didn’t do a great job of it. In the late 1700s, some investors got together and decided to build a nice, big road that would run across the middle of the state, from Portsmouth to Concord. They called the new road the New Hampshire Turnpike. Although it was a toll road, meaning people had to pay to use it, the road was in much better condition than the smaller, local roads. The turnpike was wider than most roads and had fewer potholes. It made traveling from one part of the state to another much faster and easier. Soon other turnpikes were built in New Hampshire, linking most of the regions of the state together in a road network.

First textile mill in New Hampshire

CLOSE

First textile mill in New Hampshire

The first cotton mill in New Hampshire was built in New Ipswich in 1803. It was a small mill, but it used giant machines, known as looms, to weave cloth, which would normally take a long time to weave by hand. The looms were powered by water...

Learn More

First textile mill in New Hampshire

1803

Caption:

The first cotton mill in New Hampshire was built in New Ipswich in 1803. It was a small mill, but it used giant machines, known as looms, to weave cloth, which would normally take a long time to weave by hand. The looms were powered by water. Because the looms could make more cloth faster, the owners of the mill made more money. The success of the mill encouraged others across the state to open their own textile mills. Eventually there were mills all over New Hampshire.

Louisiana Purchase

CLOSE

Louisiana Purchase

In 1803, President Thomas Jefferson bought a huge area of land from the French for $15 million. It doubled the size of America! The Louisiana Purchase included most of the land in what is now the middle of the country and extended all the way to the Pacific Ocean...

Learn More

Louisiana Purchase

1803

Caption:

In 1803, President Thomas Jefferson bought a huge area of land from the French for $15 million. It doubled the size of America! The Louisiana Purchase included most of the land in what is now the middle of the country and extended all the way to the Pacific Ocean. No one knew what this land was like, so Jefferson sent two men, Meriwether Lewis and William Clark, to explore it. They encountered all sorts of new plants, animals, and people (Native Americans!). They also found big rivers like the Mississippi and grand mountain ranges like the Rocky Mountains. Once they made it to the Pacific Ocean, they turned around and came home, but the books they wrote about their adventures across the continent made other Americans want to move west and settle on this land.

Old Man of the Mountain “discovered”

CLOSE

Old Man of the Mountain “discovered”

It wasn’t until the early 1800s that people started exploring the White Mountains, which were beautiful but rugged. Men building a road through Franconia Notch in 1805 saw a group of rocks that looked just like a giant head. They called the rock formation the Old Man of the Mountain, and soon tourists came from all over to see the Old Man...

Learn More

Old Man of the Mountain “discovered”

1805

Caption:

It wasn’t until the early 1800s that people started exploring the White Mountains, which were beautiful but rugged. Men building a road through Franconia Notch in 1805 saw a group of rocks that looked just like a giant head. They called the rock formation the Old Man of the Mountain, and soon tourists came from all over to see the Old Man. The Old Man eventually became a symbol for the state, and he often appears on all sorts of things having to do with New Hampshire, even license plates and bobbleheads!

Live free or die

CLOSE

Live free or die

New Hampshire’s most famous Revolutionary War soldier, General John Stark, used the term “Live free or die” in 1809. He was writing a letter to some fellow veterans who had organized a dinner to celebrate the anniversary of Stark’s great victory in 1777, the Battle of Bennington...

Learn More

Live free or die

1809

Caption:

New Hampshire’s most famous Revolutionary War soldier, General John Stark, used the term “Live free or die” in 1809. He was writing a letter to some fellow veterans who had organized a dinner to celebrate the anniversary of Stark’s great victory in 1777, the Battle of Bennington. Stark was too sick to attend the dinner, but instead he sent a letter. The letter praised the men for fighting in the American Revolution. Stark wrote, “Live free or die, death is not the greatest of evils.” A newspaper published Stark’s letter, and the phrase “Live free or die” seemed to stick in everyone’s minds. It wasn’t until 1945, though, that Stark’s phrase officially became the state motto of New Hampshire.

Textile mills in Lowell

CLOSE

Textile mills in Lowell

The first factories in America opened in the early 1800s when inventors found a way to use water power to make machines work. Machines could work much faster than people, even though people still needed to tend the machines...

Learn More

Textile mills in Lowell

1815

Caption:

The first factories in America opened in the early 1800s when inventors found a way to use water power to make machines work. Machines could work much faster than people, even though people still needed to tend the machines. Most of these early factories made textiles, which is another word for fabric, the kind used to make clothing, bedding, and curtains. Thousands of men, women, and children worked in the textile factories, tending to the looms, which were the machines that wove the fabric.

Merrimack River made navigable

CLOSE

Merrimack River made navigable

The Merrimack River is the largest river in New Hampshire. At a time when it was still difficult and slow to travel on roads, water travel was the fastest way to move goods and people from one place to another. People used rivers almost like they use highways today...

Learn More

Merrimack River made navigable

1815

Caption:

The Merrimack River is the largest river in New Hampshire. At a time when it was still difficult and slow to travel on roads, water travel was the fastest way to move goods and people from one place to another. People used rivers almost like they use highways today. The Merrimack River was an important highway because it was so big and it went through the center of the state. But it had many waterfalls and rough water which boats couldn’t get around, especially between Manchester and Concord. In the early 1800s, a series of locks and canals were built so boats could navigate around the falls. These changes made it possible for a boat to travel all the way from Boston to Concord.

In 1816, the state government ordered the construction of a building where they could conduct their business. It would be called the State House, and when it was finished in 1819, it was the largest building in the state. Made out of Concord granite, the State House would become the political center of the state, and it would also become a place that celebrated all the important people in New Hampshire’s history with statues and portraits.

He returned to America in 1825 and took a grand tour of all the states to celebrate America’s 50th birthday. At this dinner on the State House lawn, New Hampshire Secretary of State Philip Carrigain gave a toast to Lafayette in which he referred to New Hampshire as the Granite State. New Hampshire had already gained a reputation for the fine granite stone found in the state, which was starting to be used in buildings all over New England. The nickname stuck, and New Hampshire has been known as the Granite State ever since.

The fastest way to travel was by water on a boat, but the problem was that many rivers and lakes did not link up with each other. To connect them, people built canals so the boats could travel by water farther. In 1825, the longest canal in America opened. It was called the Erie Canal, and it ran 363 miles through the State of New York, linking the Great Lakes to the Hudson River. The Erie Canal was difficult to build, but when it was finished, it offered people a way to transport passengers and goods faster and cheaper than ever before. It also set off a wave of canal-building in America as other places constructed canals to link their waterways.

Caption:

In the 1820s, not many people lived in the White Mountains. One family, the Willeys, built a homestead near Crawford Notch. The family included a mother, father, five children, and two hired hands. In August 1826, a huge storm moved through the area and set off a massive landslide in the little valley where the Willeys lived. The landslide destroyed almost everything in the valley except the Willeys’ house. Unfortunately, when the Willeys heard the landslide begin, they left their house and tried to run away from the landslide, which didn’t work. They were all killed, even though their house miraculously survived. News traveled all over the country of the Willey tragedy and the strange story that their house was just as they left it, with beds unmade, and books and food sitting on the table. In fact, tourists started coming to the White Mountains just to see the Willeys’ house. This became the start of a tourism boom to the White Mountains. People came to see the Willeys’ house but were so impressed with the beauty of the White Mountains that they stayed for long visits and began to explore the area more.

Most people think of them in connection with the American West, where they were used for most of the 19th century. They were used all over the world, though, in places as far away as Australia. Thousands of immigrants came to Manchester to work in the mills.

Some slaves escaped to the North or to Canada where slavery was against the law, but it was very dangerous to run away. A runaway slave who was captured could be beaten or even killed by their owner. In 1849, a slave named Harriet Tubman escaped from slavery and fled to the North. Remarkably, she returned to the South 13 times to rescue other slaves over the next 10 years. In 1860-61, the southern states chose to leave the U.S. government and form their own country, one where they could keep their slaves. The northern states said they could not leave the American union. This led to the Civil War, which was a terrible war when Americans fought other Americans. The North eventually won the war, the United States remained one big country, and the slaves were all set free. But over 600,000 Americans died in the fighting.

Cog Railway opens

Caption:

An inventor named Sylvester Marsh loved the views from the top of Mount Washington, the highest peak in the Northeast. But he thought there must be an easier way to get to the top than climbing up 6,000 feet. He developed a special kind of train, called a cog railway, that could climb such a steep terrain. The cog railway used gears to pull the train up the side of the mountain. It also had special brakes that would keep the train from coming back down the mountain too fast. It took a long time for Marsh to convince people that his train would work. In fact, people used to make fun of his idea by calling it the “railway to the moon,” since they thought Marsh had as much chance to build a train that ran to the top of a mountain as he did building one that went to the moon. But finally, he raised enough money to build it. On July 3, 1869, the first cog train, which Marsh called “Old Peppersass,” climbed to the top of Mount Washington. It was the first cog railway in the world.

Caption:

Many of the state’s small towns saw a decline in their population. Governor Frank Rollins came up with the idea that every New Hampshire town should hold an Old Home Week as a way to celebrate their community. The townspeople in each community would decide how they wanted to celebrate, but most towns held picnics, concerts, baseball games, plays, dinners, parades, and fireworks. Rollins also encouraged towns to write letters to people who used to live there but had moved away, inviting them back again to see old friends at the celebration. When these visitors returned, they often donated money to the town to build a new building or create a park for the townspeople. New Hampshire towns stopped holding Old Home Week in the 1920s, but many began the tradition again in the 1990s or 2000s, only now the celebration usually lasts a day. Caption:

World War I was such a big war with such terrible fighting that people thought it could never happen again. That’s why it is sometimes called “the war to end all wars.” Most of the fighting was in Europe between France, England, and Russia on one side, and Germany and Austria-Hungary on the other. The invention of new machines--like tanks, machine guns, and poison gas—meant that many more soldiers died faster than in previous wars. In four years of fighting, over 10 million soldiers died. America stayed out of the war until 1917 but then helped England and France finally win in 1918.

Caption:

In April 1917, the United States joined World War I, fighting on the side of England and France. America had a small army at the time, so the government encouraged volunteers to join up. Thousands of young men from New Hampshire signed up for the army. They were placed all in one division, which quickly became called the Yankee Division because it was full of soldiers from the New England (Yankee) states, such as New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Connecticut, Maine, Vermont, and Rhode Island. The Yankee Division were the first American soldiers to arrive in Europe to fight the war, and they stayed in Europe until the war ended. They were trained by French officers, who thought that the Yankees were so good at throwing grenades because they were used to throwing baseballs!

Now, the national forest contains almost 800,000 acres of land. Thousands of people visit it every year to hike, ski, or simply enjoy the beauty of the mountains.

Potato drive campaign

1918

Caption:

During World War I, Granite State farmers grew food for the soldiers serving in Europe. The U.S. government told the farmers what crops to plant and how much to plant to cover the needs of the army. But in the spring of 1918, New Hampshire farmers discovered that they had grown too many potatoes. Not wanting the potatoes to go to waste, state officials began the Great Potato Drive, encouraging everyone to eat as many potatoes as possible since they had a surplus. State officials also hoped that if people ate more potatoes they would eat less flour and wheat, which the army needed. The slogan for the Great Potato Drive was “Buy and Eat Potatoes Now.”

Over the next several weeks, it began broadcasting all sorts of programs, including sports, news, and music. The people within range of KDKA’s signal loved this new form of entertainment. Radio stations sprang up all over the country in just a few years, and soon almost every household in America owned a radio. Families often sat around the radio in the evening and listened together to whatever was on. Because radio communications were immediate and could reach thousands or even millions of people at a time, radio is considered the first form of mass communication.

Caption:

New Hampshire has an official state dog—the chinook. All chinooks are descended from one dog, who was named, unsurprisingly, Chinook. Chinook was a sled dog, who was trained to survive in extreme weather conditions. His owner, a New Hampshire man named Arthur Treadwell Walden, took Chinook with him when he went an expedition to explore the South Pole. Chinook was the lead dog on a team of 90 sled dogs who brought supplies to the explorers and helped keep them alive. The expedition’s leader, Admiral Robert Byrd, later said that without Chinook and the other dogs on the team, the expedition to the South Pole would have failed.

Caption:

The Great Depression was a 10-year period in American history when the American economy did very poorly. It started with the stock market crash of 1929. Soon after the crash, many businesses closed. Millions of people lost their jobs. Lots of people struggled to find enough food to eat. To help all the people struggling in America, the U.S. government hired thousands of people to build big construction projects like bridges and dams, establish national parks with trail systems, and create public art like statues and murals. The government also opened soup kitchens to feed people and shelters so people would have some place to sleep. The federal government began to play a much bigger role in people’s lives during the Great Depression.

Still others made jewelry or furniture. To promote all the different kinds of art in the state, a group of people formed the League of New Hampshire Craftsmen in 1931. The league not only encouraged people to buy art from local craftsmen but it also established a program so that craftsmen could teach others how to make traditional handicrafts. In 1934, they held the first craft festival where people could buy locally made crafts and see how artists create their works. The festival still happens every year in August.

In 1936, New Hampshire’s largest factory, the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company, closed. The company had owned dozens of huge buildings in Manchester, which now stood empty. It was the end of an era. Skiiers would basically hold onto a rope that was pulled up the mountain, but even that was a lot of work to get dragged so far up such steep inclines. There are still places in New Hampshire today where the damage from the Hurricane of 1938 can be seen, such as Turkey Pond in Concord.

First presidential primary

1952

Caption:

New Hampshire is now famous for holding the first-in-the-nation presidential primary, which means the people of New Hampshire get to pick before people in other states who should run for president. A presidential primary is not an election to see who becomes president—it’s an election to see who will be nominated to run for president by one of the major political parties, the Democrats and the Republicans. The first modern presidential primary was held in New Hampshire in 1952. In that year, some of the candidates spent a lot of time in the Granite State talking to voters, listening to their concerns, and convincing voters to support them, which worked! They did better than the candidates who didn’t really run campaigns in the state. The media also paid a lot of attention to the campaign. The primary election made national headlines as all Americans learned more about the men who wanted to become president by watching how they did in New Hampshire. Ever since then, the Granite State has been considered the first stop on the road to winning the presidency.

Rosa Parks arrested

Caption:

Even though slavery had ended at the end of the Civil War, many African Americans still were not treated equally with other Americans. For example, for many years African Americans went to different schools than other Americans, had to use different drinking fountains, and were only allowed to sit in some sections of movie theaters. They even had to sit in the back of busses! This system was called segregation. In 1955, a woman in Montgomery, Alabama, named Rosa Parks decided she didn’t want to be treated like a second-class citizen anymore, and she refused to sit in the African-American section of the bus. She was arrested for challenging segregation laws, but her arrest set off a chain of protests for more equality for African-Americans. This effort became known as the civil rights movement. It took many years and lots of protests, but eventually segregation ended in America.

Shepard's flight was an important step because it proved that people could go to space and return safely.

Caption:

In the early 1970s, a Greek billionaire wanted to build an oil refinery on New Hampshire's Great Bay. An oil refinery turns crude oil into petroleum products that people use every day, like gasoline or heating oil. The billionaire planned to ship oil to the coast of New Hampshire in giant ships and then pump it in underwater pipelines to the refinery. Some Granite Staters liked this plan because it would bring jobs to the state and lower the price of oil for everyone. Others did not like it because they worried that it would damage the environment. For example, if the underwater pipes leaked, billions of gallons of oil would be dumped in New Hampshire's waters. This would kill all the plant and animal life in the area. A group called "Save Our Shores" worked to prevent the oil refinery. At town meeting in Durham in 1974, the project was voted down. The refinery was never built.
